dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl Showalter is driving.  Gaear Grimsrud stares blankly out. After a long beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Pancakes Hause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stop at Pancakes Hause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you, nuts?  We had pancakes for breakfast.  I gotta go somewhere I can get a shot and a beer - and a steak maybe. Not more fuckin' pancakes.  Come on. Grimsrud gives him a sour look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Come on, man.  Okay, here's an idea.  We'll stop outside of Brainerd.  I know a place there we can get laid.  Wuddya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fuckin' hungry now, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, Jesus - I'm sayin', we'll stop for pancakes, then we'll get laid.  Wuddya think?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAFSON OLDS GARAGE
dialogues.text: Jerry is sitting in his glassed-in salesman's cubicle jus off the showroom floor.  On the other side of his desk si an irate customer and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sat here right in this room and went over this and over this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, but that TruCoat -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sat right here and said I didn't want no TruCoat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, but I'm sayin', that TruCoat, you don't get it and you get oxidization problems.  It'll cost you a heck of lot more'n five hunnert -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sittin' here, you're talkin' in circles!  You're talkin' like we didn't go over this already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, but this TruCoat -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had us a deal here for nine- teen-five.  You sat there and darned if you didn't tell me you'd get this car, these options, WITHOUT THE SEALANT, for nine- teen-five!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm not sayin' I didn't -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called me twenty minutes ago and said you had it!  Ready to make delivery, ya says!  Come on down and get it!  And here ya are and you're wastin' my time and you're wastin' my wife's time and I'm payin' nineteen-five for this vehicle here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay, I'll talk to my boss... He rises, and, as he leaves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  See, they install that TruCoat at the factory, there's nothin' we can do, but I'll talk to my boss. The couple watch him go to a nearby cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys here - these guys! It's always the same!  It's always more!  He's a liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went over this and over this -

dialogues.speaker: NEARBY CUBICLE
dialogues.text: Jerry sits perched on the desk of another salesman who is eating lunch as he watches a hockey game on a small porta TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're goin' to the Gophers on Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have an extra ticket there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're playin' the Buckeyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya kiddin'!

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S CUBICLE
dialogues.text: Jerry re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he never done this before, but seein' as it's special circumstances and all, he says I can knock one hunnert off that TruCoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred!  You lied to me, Mr. Lundegaard.  You're a bald-faced liar! Jerry sits staring at his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  A fucking liar -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bucky, please! Jerry mumbles into his lap:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hunnert's the best we can do here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Christ's sake, where's my goddamn checkbook.  Let's get this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a restaurant with many big rigs parked nearby, a a motel with an outsize Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox flanking its sign:  BLUE OX MOTEL.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Carl Showalter and Gaear Grimsrud are in the twin beds having sex with two truck-stop hookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ya go, sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nnph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yeah.  Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The couples like in their respective beds, gazing at the offscreen TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -  Johnny's guests tonight will be Lee Majors, George Wendt, and Steve Boutsikaros from the San Diego Zoo, so keep that dial -

dialogues.speaker: LUNDEGAARD KITCHEN
dialogues.text: We hear a morning show on television.  Jean Lundegaard is making coffee in the kitchen as Scott eats cereal at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' about your potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a C student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet you're gettin' C grades. It's this disparity there that concerns your dad and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what a disparity is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Well, that's why we don't want ya goin' out fer hockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man! The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  What's the big deal?  It's an hour -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. She picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, hiya, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hiya, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, he's still here - I'll catch him for ya. She holds the phone away and calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah... Jerry enters in shirtsleeves and tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah, okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Dad, there is no fucking way -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, let's watch the language - He takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin', Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's goin' on there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing, Wade.  How ya doin' there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan Grossman looked at your proposal.  Says it's pretty sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kiddin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might be innarested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kiddin'!  I'd need the cash pretty quick there.  In order to close the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come by at 2:30 and we'll talk about it.  If your numbers are right, Stan says its pretty sweet.  Stan Grossman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.
Click.  Dial tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAFSON OLD GARAGE
dialogues.text: Jerry wanders through the service area where cars are bei worked on.  He stops by an Indian in blue jeans who is looking at the underside of a car that sits on a hydrauli lift with a cage light hanging off its innards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Shep, how ya doin' there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, ya know those two fellas ya put me in touch with, up there in Fargo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put you in touch with Grimsrud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yah, but he had a buddy there.  He, uh -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't vouch for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's okay, I just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vouch for Grimsrud.  Who's his buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him.  Don't vouch for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's okay, he's a buddy of the guy ya vouched for, so I'm not worryin'.  I just, I was wonderin', see, I gotta get in touch with 'em for, I might not need it anymore, sumpn's happenin', see -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, well, see, I did that, and I haven't been able to get 'em, so I thought you maybe'd know an alternate number or what have ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Jerry slaps his fist into his open palm and snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well, real good, then.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Carl is driving.  Grimsrud stares out front. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Look at that.  Twin Cities. IDS Building, the big glass one. Tallest skyscraper in the Midwest. After the Sears, uh, Chicago... You never been to Minneapolis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Would it kill you to say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "No." First thing you've said in the last four hours.  That's a, that's a fountain of conversation, man.  That's a geyser.  I mean, whoa, daddy, stand back, man.  Shit, I'm sittin' here driving, man, doin' all the driving, whole fuckin' way from Brainerd, drivin', tryin' to, you know, tryin' to chat, keep our spirits up, fight the boredom of the road, and you can't say one fucking thing just in the way of conversation. Grimsurd smokes, gazing out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Well, fuck it, I don't have to talk either, man.  See how you like it... He drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Total silence...

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S CUBICLE
dialogues.text: He is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, real good.  How you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good, Mr. Lundegaard. You're damned hard to get on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, it's pretty darned busy here, but that's the way we like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for sure.  Now, I just need, on these last, these financing documents you sent us, I can't read the serial numbers of the vehicles on here, so I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I already got the, it's okay, the loans are in place, I already got the, the what, the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the three hundred and twenty thousand dollars, you got the money last month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, so we're all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the vehicles you were borrowing on, I just can't read the serial numbers on your applicaton.  Maybe if you could just read them to me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the deal's already done, I already got the money -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we have an audit here, I just have to know that these vehicles you're financing with this money, that they really exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, well, they exist all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they do - ha ha!  But I can't read their serial numbers here.  So if you could read me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, but see, I don't have 'em in front a me - why don't I just fax you over a copy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, fax is no good, that's what I have and I can't read the darn thing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, okay, I'll have my girl send you over a copy, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, because if I can't correlate this note with the specific vehicles, then I gotta call back that money -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, how much money was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred and twenty thousand dollars.  See, I gotta correlate that money with the cars it's being lent on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, no problem, I'll just fax that over to ya, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, fax is -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean send it over.  I'll shoot it right over to ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, real good, then.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: A morning-show host in an apron stands behind a counter o kitchen set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I seperate the - how the heck do I get the egg out of the shell without breaking it? Jean Lundegaard is curled up on the couch with a cup of coffee, watching the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just prick a little hole in the end and blow! Jean smiles as we hear laughter and applause from the stu audience.  She hears something else - a faint scraping so - and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here goes nothing. The scraping sound persists.  Jean sets down her coffee c and rises. From the studio audience:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awoooo!

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: We track toward the back door.  A curtain is stretched ti across its window. Jean pulls the curtain back.  Bright sunlight amplified b snow floods in. A man in an orange ski mask looks up from the lock. Jean gasps, drops the curtain, rutns and runs into - - a taller man, also in a ski mask, already in the house. We hear the crack of the back-door window being smashed. The tall man - Gaear Grimsrud - grabs Jean's wrist. She screams, staring at her own imprisoned wrist, then wr her gaping mouth around Grimsrud's gloved thumb and bites down hard. He drops her wrist.  As Carl enters, she races up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unguent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Grimsurd looks at his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need ... unguent.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS BEDROOM
dialogues.text: As the two men enter, a door at the far side is slamming shut.  A cord snakes in under the door.

dialogues.speaker: MASTER BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Jean, sobbing, frantically pushes at buttons on the princ phone. The phone pops out of her hands, jangles across the tile floor, smashes against the door and then bounces away, it cord ripped free. With a groaning sound, the door shifts in its frame.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Grimsrud has a crowbar jammed in between the bathroom doo and frame, and is working it.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Jean crosses to a high window above the toilet and throws open.  Snow that had drifted against the window sifts lightly in.  Jean steps up onto the toilet. The door creaks, moving as one piece in its frame. Jean glances back as she steps up from the toilet seat to the tank. The groaning of the door ends with the wood around its kn splintering and the knob itself falling out onto the floo The door swings open. Grimsrud and Carl enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room empty, window open. Carl strides to the window and hoists himself out. Grimsrud opens the medicine cabinet and delicately taps aside various bottles and tubes, seeking the proper ungue He finds a salve but after a moment sets it down, noticin something in the mirror. The shower curtain is drawn around the tub. He steps toward it. As he reaches for the curtain, it explodes outward, anima by thrashing limbs. Jean, screaming, tangled in the curtain, rips it off its rings and stumbles out into the bedroom.  Grimsrud follow

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Jean rushes toward the door, cloaked by the shower curtai but awkwardly trying to push it off.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS LANDING
dialogues.text: Still thrashing, Jean crashes against the upstairs railin trips on the curtain and falls, thumping crazily down the stairs. Grimsrud trots down after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade sits behind his desk; another man rises as Jerry enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin' there, Stan?  How are ya, Wade? Stan Grossman shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see ya again, Jerry.  If these numbers are right, this looks pretty sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, those numbers are all right, bleemee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is do-able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, thanks, Stan, it's a pretty -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of finder's fee were you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The financials are pretty thorough, so the only thing we don't know is your fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  My fee?  Wade, what the heck're you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan and I're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're good to loan in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we never talked about your fee for bringin' it to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but, Wade, see, I was bringin' you this deal for you to loan me the money to put in.  It's my deal here, see? Wade scowls, looks at Stan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry - we thought you were bringin' us an investment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, right -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sayin' - what're you sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sayin' that we put in all the money and you collect when it pays off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  I - I'd, I'd - pay you back the principal, and interest - heck, I'd go - one over prime -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not a bank, Jerry. Wade is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the heck, Jerry, if I wanted bank interest on seven hunnert'n fifty thousand I'd go to Midwest Federal.  Talk to Bill Diehl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at Norstar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, see, I don't need a finder's fee, I need - finder's fee's, what, ten percent, heck that's not gonna do it for me.  I need the principal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, we're not just going to give you seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the heck were you thinkin'? Heck, if I'm only gettin' bank interest, I'd look for complete security.  Heck, FDIC.  I don't see nothin' like that here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, but I - okay, I would, I'd guarantee ya your money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talkin' about your damn word, Jerry.  Geez, what the heck're you?...  Well, look, I don't want to cut you out of the loop, but his here's a good deal. I assume, if you're not innarested, you won't mind if we move on it independently.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: We are high and wide on the office building's parking lot Jerry emerges wrapped in a parka, his arms sticking stiff out at his sides, his breath vaporizing.  He goes to his car, opens its front door, pulls out a red plastic scrape and starts methodically scraping off the thin crust of ic that has developed on his windshield. The scrape-scrape-scrape sound carries in the frigid air. Jerry goes into a frenzy, banging the scraper against the windshield and the hood of his car. The tantrum passes.  Jerry stands pantin, staring at noth in particular. Scrape-scrape-scrape - he goes back to work on the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: A beat, silent but for a key scraping at the lock. The door swings open and Jerry edges in, looking about, holding a sack of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hon? He shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Got the growshries... He has already seen the shower curtain on the floor.  He frowns, pokes at it with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Hon?

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Jerry walks in.  He sets the groceries down on the toilet tank. He looks at the open window, through which snow still sif in.  He shuts it. He picks up the small tube of uguent that sits on the sin frowns at it, puts it back in the medicine chest. He looks at the shower curtain rod holding empty rings.

dialogues.speaker: FOYER
dialogues.text: Once again we are looking at the rumpled shower curtain. From another room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, Wade, I - it's Jerry, I. Then, slightly more agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah, Wade, it's, I, it's Jerry... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Wade, it's Jerry, I - we gotta talk, Wade, it's terrible... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jerry stands in wide shot, hands on hips, looking down at telephone. After a motionless beat he picks up the phone and punches a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah, Wade Gustafson, please.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Hold in black. A slow tilt down from night sky brings the head of a larg paper-mache figure into frame.  It is a flannel-shirt woodsman carrying a double-edged ax over one shoulder.  A we hear the rumble of an approaching car, the continuing tilt and boom down brings us down the woodsman's body to pedestal. A sweep of headlights illuminates a sign on the pedestal: WELCOME TO BRAINDERD - HOME OF PAUL BUNYAN. The headlights sweep off and a car hums past and on into background.  The two-lane highway is otherwise empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl drives.  Grimsrud smokes and gazes out the window. From the back seat we hear whimpering. Grimsrud turns to look. Jean lies bound and curled on the back seat underneath a tarpaulin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up or I'll throw you back in the trunk, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez.  That's more'n I've heard you say all week. Grimsrud stares at him, then turns back to the window. At a loud WHOOP Carl starts and looks back out the rear window.  Fifty yards behind a state trooper has turned on his gumballs. Carl eases the car onto the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, shit, the tags... Grimsrud looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  It's just the tags.  I never put my tags on the car.  Don't worry, I'll take care of this. He looks into the back seat as the car bounces and slows the gravel shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Let's keep still back there, lady, or we're gonna have to, ya know, to shoot ya. Grimsrud stares at Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Hey!  I'll take care of this! Both cars have stopped.  Carl looks up at the rear-view mirror. The trooper is stopped on the shoulder just behind them, writing in his citation book. Carl watches. We hear the trooper's door open. The trooper walks up the shoulder, one hand resting light on top of his holster, his breath steaming in the cold ni air. Carl opens his window as the trooper draws up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I help you, officer? The trooper scans the inside of the car, taking his time. Grimsrud smokes and gazes calmly out his window. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a new car, then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly is, officer.  Still got that smell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're required to display temporary tags, either in the plate area or taped inside the back window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see your license and registration please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. He reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I was gonna tape up the temporary tag, ya know, to be in full compliance, but it, uh, it, uh ... must a slipped my mind... He extends his wallet toward the trooper, a folded fifty- dollar bill protruding from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  So maybe the best thing would be to take care of that, right here in Brainerd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my license and regis- tration.  I wanna be in compliance. He forces a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I was just thinking I could take care of it right here.  In Brainerd. The policeman thoughtfully pats the fifty into the billfo and hands the billfold back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that back in your pocket, please. Carl's nervous smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  And step out of the car, please, sir. Grimsrud, smiling thinly, shakes his head. There is a whimpering sound. The policeman hesitates. Another sound. The policeman leans forward into the car, listening. Grimsrud reaches across Carl, grabs the trooper by the ha and slams his head down onto the car door. The policeman grunts, digs awkwardly for footing outside throws an arm for balance against the outside of the car. With his free hand, Grimsrud pops the glove compartment. brings a gun out and reaches across Carl and shoots - BAN into the back of the trooper's head. Jean screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. He releases the policeman. The policeman's head slides out the window and his body flops back onto the street. Carl looks out at the cop in the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa...  Whoa, Daddy. Grimsrud takes the trooper's hat off of Carl's lap and sa it out the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take care of it.  Boy, you are smooth smooth, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, Daddy. Jean, for some reason, screams again.  Then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear him off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl leans down to hoist up the body. Headlights appear:  an oncoming car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimsrud notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car approaches, slowing. Carl, with the trooper's body hoisted halfway up, is froz in the headlights. The car accelerates and roars past and away.  We just mak out the silhouettes of two occupants in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimsrud slides into the driver's seat.  He squeals into turn, the driver's door slamming shut with his spin. Small red tail lights fishtail up ahead.  The pursued car churns up fine snow. Grimsrud takes the cigarette from his mouth and stubs it his ashtray.  We hear the churning of the car wheels and pinging of snow clods and salt on the car's underside. In the back seat, Jean starts screaming. Grimsrud is not gaining on the tail lights. He fights with the wheel as his car swims on the road fac The red tail lights ahead start to turn.  With a distant crunching sound, they disappear. The headlights now show only empty road, starting to turn Grimsrud frowns and slows. His headlights show the car up ahead off the road, crumpl around a telephone pole, having failed to hold a turn. Grimsrud brakes. Jean slides off the back seat and thumps into the legwell Grimsrud sweeps his gun off the front seat, throws open h door and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrecked car's headlights shine off into a snowfield abutting the highway.  A young man in a down parka is limping across the snowfield, away from the wrecked car. Grimsrud strides calmly out after the injured boy.  He raises his gun and fires. With a poof of feathers, a hole opens up in the boy's bac and he pitches into the snow. Grimsrud walks up to the wreck and peers in its half-open door. A young woman is trapped inside the twisted wreckage, injured. Snow swirls in the headlights of the wreck. Grimsrud raises his gun and fires.

dialogues.speaker: AN OIL PAINTING
dialogues.text: A blue-winged teal in flight over a swampy marshland.  Th room in which it hangs is dark.  We hear off-screen snori We track off to reveal an easel upon which we see a half- completed oil of a grey mallard. The continuing track reveals a couple in bed, sleeping. man, fortyish, pajama-clad, is big, and big-bellied.  His mouth is agape.  He snores.  His arms are flung over a wo in her thirties, wearing a nightie, mouth also open, not snoring. We hold for a long beat on their regular breathing and snoring. The phone rings. The woman stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, geez... She reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Hi, it's Marge... The man stirs and clears his throat with a long deep rumb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Oh, my.  Where?...  Yah... Oh, geez... The man sits up, gazes stupidly about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Okay.  There in a jif... Real good, then. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  You can sleep, hon.  It's early yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. The man swings his legs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fix ya some eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, hon.  I gotta run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta eat a breakfast, Marge. I'll fix ya some eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you can sleep, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya gotta eat a breakfast... He clears his throat with another deep rumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I'll fix ya some eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Norm.

dialogues.speaker: PLATE
dialogues.text: Leavings of a huge plate of eggs, ham, toast. Wider, we see Marge now wearing a beige police uniform. patch on one arm says BRAINERD POLICE DEPARTMENT.  She we a heavy belt holding a revolver, walkie-talkie and variou other jangling police impedimenta.  Norm is in a dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, hon.  Time to shove off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love ya, Margie. As she struggles into a parka:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love ya, hon. He is exiting back to the bedroom; she exits out the fron door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn.  Marge is making her way down the icy front stoop t her prowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm sits back onto the bed, shrugging off his robe.  Off screen we hear the front door open.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Marge stamps the snow off her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prowler needs a jump.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Two police cars and an ambulance sit idling at the side o the road, a pair of men inside each car. The first car's driver door opens and a figure in a parka emerges, holding two styrofoam cups.  His partner leans across the seat to close the door after him. The reverse shows Marge approaching from her own squad ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Lou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie.  Thought you might need a little warm-up. He hands her one of the cups of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, thanks a bunch.  So what's the deal, now?  Gary says triple homicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, looks pretty bad.  Two of'm're over here. Marge looks around as they start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - it's cold, Margie.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE WRECK
dialogues.text: Laid out in the early morning light is the wrecked car, a pair of footprints leading out to a man in a bright orang parka face down in the bloodstained snow, and one pair of footsteps leading back to the road. Marge is peering into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, geez.  So...  Aw, geez. Here's the second one...  It's in the head and the ... hand there, I guess that's a defensive wound.  Okay. Marge looks up from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Where's the state trooper? Lou, up on the shoulder, jerks his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back there a good piece.  In the ditch next to his prowler. Marge looks around at the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so we got a state trooper pulls someone over, we got a shooting, and these folks drive by, and we got a high-speed pursuit, ends here, and this execution-type deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be very surprised if our suspect was from Brainerd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. Marge is studying the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  And I'll tell you what, from his footprints he looks like a big fella - Marge suddenly doubles over, putting her head between her knees down near the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya see something down there, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh - I just, I think I'm gonna barf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, you okay, Margie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine - it's just morning sickness. She gets up, sweeping snow from her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Well, that passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Now I'm hungry again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had breakfast yet, Margie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah.  Norm made some eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?  Well, what now, d'ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go take a look at that trooper.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE STATE TROOPER'S CAR
dialogues.text: Marge's prowler is parked nearby. Marge is on her hands and knees by a body down in the dit again looking at footprints in the snow.  She calls up to the road:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two of 'em, Lou!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, this guy's smaller than his buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah?

dialogues.speaker: DOWN IN THE DITCH
dialogues.text: In the foreground is the head of the state trooper, facin us.  Peering at it from behind, still on her hands and knees, is Marge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Pete's sake. She gets up, clapping the snow off her hands, and climbs of the ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it look, Marge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's got his gun on his hip there, and he looks like a nice enough guy.  It's a real shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't monkeyed with his car there, have ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. She is looking at the prowler, which still idles on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody shut his lights.  I guess the little guy sat in there, waitin' for his buddy t'come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, woulda been cold out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, yah.  Ya think, is Dave open yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think he's mixed up in -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I just wanna get Norm some night crawlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge is driving; Lou sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look in his citation book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah... He looks at his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Last vehicle he wrote in was a tan Ciera at 2:18 a.m. Under the plate number he put DLR - I figure they stopped him or shot him before he could finish fillin' out the tag number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I got the state lookin' for a Ciera with a tag startin' DLR. They don't got no match yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I agree with you a hunnert percent on your policework, there, Lou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, I think that vehicle there probly had dealer plates.  DLR?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Lou gazes out the window, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Geez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Say, Lou, ya hear the one about the guy who couldn't afford personalized plates, so he went and changed his name to J2L 4685?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, that's a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: The police car enters with a whoosh and hums down a strai ruled empty highway, cutting a landscape of flat and perf white.

dialogues.speaker: EMBERS FAMILY RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman sit in a booth, sipping coffee.  Outside the window, snow falls from a gunmetal s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -  All's I know is, ya got a problem, ya call a professional!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  They said no cops!  They were darned clear on that, Wade!  They said you call the cops and we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a course they're gonna say that!  But where's my protection? They got Jean here!  I give these sons a bitches a million dollars, where's my guarantee they're gonna let her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million dollars is a lot a damn money!  And there they are, they got my daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, but think this thing through here, Wade.  Ya give 'em what they want, why wont' they let her go? You gotta listen to me on this one, Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, you don't know!  You're just whistlin' Dixie here!  I'm sayin', the cops, they can advise us on this!  I'm sayin' call a professional!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  No cops!  That's final!  This is my deal here, Wade!  Jean is my wife here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta tell ya, Wade, I'm leanin' to Jerry's viewpoint here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta protect Jean.  These - we're not holdin' any cards here, Wade, they got all of 'em.  So they call the shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're darned tootin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...  Why don't we... He saws a finger under his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Stan, I'm thinkin' we should offer 'em half a million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on here, no way, Wade! No way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not horse-trading here, Wade, we just gotta bite the bullet on this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the next step here, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna call, give me instructions for a drop.  I'm supposed to have the money ready tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: THE CASHIER
dialogues.text: She rings up two dollars forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was everything today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, real good now.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Snow continues to fall.  Jerry and Stan stand bundled in their parkas and galoshes near a row of beached vehicles. Wade sits behind the wheel of an idling Lincoln, waiting Stan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  We'll get the money together. Don't worry about it, Jerry.  Now, d'you want anyone at home, with you, until they call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I - they don't want - they're just s'posed to be dealin' with me, they were real clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. Jerry pounds his mittened hands together against the cold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, they said no one listenin' in, they'll be watchin', ya know. Maybe it's all bull, but like you said, Stan, they're callin' the shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  And Scotty, is he gonna be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, geez, Scotty.  I'll go talk to him. There is a tap at the horn from Wade, and Stan gets into Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll call. The Lincoln spits snow as it grinds out of the lot and fishtails out onto the boulevard.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Scotty lies on the bed, weeping.  Jerry enters and perche uncomfortably on the edge of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  How ya doin' there, Scotty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad!  What're they doing?  Wuddya think they're doin' with Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Scotty.  They're not gonna want to hurt her any. These men, they just want money, see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if - what if sumpn goes wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, nothin's goin' wrong here. Grandad and I, we're - we're makin' sure this gets handled right. Scott snorfles and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I really think we should call the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  We can't let anyone know about this thing!  We gotta play ball with these guys - you ask Stan Grossman, he'll tell ya the same thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna get Mom back for ya, but we gotta play ball.  Ya know, that's the deal.  Now if Lorraine calls, or Sylvia, you just say that Mom is in Florida with Pearl and Marty... Scotty starts to weep again.  Jerry stares down at his la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  That's the best we can do here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a lakeside cabin surrounded by white.  A brown Cier with dealer plates is pulling into the drive. Grimsrud climbs out of the passenger seat as Carl climbs of the driver's.  Grimsrud opens the back door and, with arm on her elbow, helps Jean out.  She has her hands tied behind her and a black hood over her head. With a cry, she swings her elbow out of Grimsrud's grasp lurches away across the front lawn.  Grimsrud moves to retrieve her but Carl, grinning, lays a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it. They both look out at the front lawn, Grimsrud expressionless, Carl smiling. With muffled cries, the hooded woman lurches across the unbroken snow, staggering this way and that, stumbling on the uneven terrain. She stops, stands still, her hooded head swaying. She lurches out in an arbitrary direction.  Going downhil she reels, staggers, and falls face-first into the snow, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha ha ha ha ha ha!  Jesus! Grimsrud, still expressionless, breaks away from Carl's restraining hand to retrieve her.

dialogues.speaker: BRAINERD POLICE HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: We track behind Marge as she makes her way across the flo greeting various officers.  She holds a small half-full paper sack. Beyond her we see a small glassed-in cublcle.  Norm sits the desk inside with a box lunch spread out in front of h There is lettering on the cubicle's glass door:  BRAINERD PD. CHIEF GUNDERSON. Marge enters and sits behind the desk, detaching her walk talkie from her utility belt to accomodate the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, hon. She slides the paper sack toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brought ya some lunch, Margie. What're those, night crawlers? He looks inside. The bottom of the sack is full of fat, crawling earthworm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.  Thanks for lunch.  What do we got here, Arbie's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. She starts eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  How's the paintin' goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good.  Found out the Hautmans are entering a painting this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, hon, you're better'n them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're good, Norm, but you're better'n them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, ya think? He leans over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, ya got Arbie's all o'er me. Lou enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Norm, how's the paintin' goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too bad.  You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we doin' on that vehicle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No motels registered any tan Ciera last night.  But the night before, two men checked into the Blue Ox registering a Ciera and leavin' the tag space blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, that's a good lead.  The Blue Ox, that's that trucker's joint out there on I-35?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Owner was on the desk then, said these two guys had company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge's prowler is parked in an otherwise empty lot.  Sno drifts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge sits talking with two young women at one end of an elevated dance platform.  The club, not yet open for business, is deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you girls from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeSeure.  But I went to high school in White Bear Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I want you to tell me what these fellas looked like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the little guy, he was kinda funny-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.  Just funny-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you be any more specific?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't really say.  He wasn't circumcised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he funny-looking apart from that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you were having sex with the little fella, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you can tell me about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Like I say, he was funny-looking. More'n most people even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about the other fella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a little older.  Looked like the Marlboro man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Maybe I'm sayin' that cause he smoked Marlboros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A subconscious-type thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, that can happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said they were goin' to the Twin Cities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Is that useful to ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you bet, yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now dusk.  The brown Ciera with dealer plates still sits in the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track in on Jean Lundegaard, who sits tied in a chair with the black hood still over her head.  As we track in, hear inarticulate cursing, intermittent banging and loud static. We track in on Gaear Grimsrud, who sits smoking a cigaret and expressionlessly gazing offscreen. We track in on Carl Showalter, who stands over an old bla and-white television.  It plays nothing but snow.  Carl i banging on it as he mutters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...days ... be here for days with a - DAMMIT! - a goddamn mute ... nothin' to do ... and the fucking - DAMMIT!... Each "dammit" brings a pound of his fist on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  TV doesn't even ... plug me in, man...  Gimmee a - DAMMIT! - signal...  Plug me into the ozone, baby...  Plug me into the ozone - FUCK!... With one last bang we cut:

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE TELEVISION SET
dialogues.text: In extreme close-up an insect is lugging a worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bark beetle carries the worm to the nest ... where it will feed its young for up to six weeks... A pull back from the screen reveals that we are in Marge' house. Marge and Norm are watching television in bed.  From the we hear insects chirring. After a long beat, silence except for the TV, Marge murmu still looking at the set:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Well, I'm turnin' in, Norm. Also looking at the TV:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Oh, yah? Marge rolls over and Norm continues to watch. We hold.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Hold. A snowflake drops through the black. Another flake. It starts snowing.

dialogues.speaker: BRAINERD MAIN STREET
dialogues.text: The lone traffic light blinks slowly, steadily, red.  Sno sifts down.  There is no other movement.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL BUNYAN
dialogues.text: We are looking up at the bottom-lit statue.  Snow falls.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Snow drops away.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The bedroom is dark.  Norm is snoring. The phone rings. Marge gropes in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, is this Marge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie Olmstead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Well, yah.  Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mike Yanagita.  Ya know - Mike Yanagita.  Remember me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Mike Yanagita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah! Marge props herself up next to the still-sleeping Norm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, yah, course I remember. How are ya?  What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, geez.  It's quarter to eleven. I hope I dint wake you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, I'm down in the Twin Cities and I was just watching on TV about these shootings up in Brainderd, and I saw you on the news there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought, geez, is that Margie Olmstead?  I can't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, that's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how the heck are ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, ya know.  Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah - how are you doon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, it's been such a long time, Mike.  It's great to hear from ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah...  Yah, yah.  Geeze, Margie!

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAFSON OLDS GARAGE
dialogues.text: Jerry is on the sales floor, showing a customer a vehicle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, ya got yer, this loaded here, this has yer independent, uh, yer slipped differential, uh, yer rack- and-pinion steering, yer alarm and radar, and I can give it to ya with a heck of a sealant, this TruCoat stuff, it'll keep the salt off -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, I don't need no sealant though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, you don't need that.  Now were you thinking of financing here? You oughta be aware a this GMAC plan they have now, it's really super -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, ya got a call here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S CUBICLE
dialogues.text: He sits in and picks up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Lundegaard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Jerry, you got this phone to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know who this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yah, I got an idea.  How's that Ciera workin' out for ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Circumstances have changed, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things have changed.  Circumstances, Jerry.  Beyond the, uh ... acts of God, force majeure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the - how's Jean? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Who's Jean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife!  What the - how's -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jean's okay.  But there's three people up in Brainerd who aren't so okay, I'll tell ya that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the heck're you talkin' about? Let's just finish up this deal here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood has been shed, Jerry. Jerry sits dumbly.  The voice solemnly repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Blood has been shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the heck d'ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three people.  In Brainerd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, geez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  And we need more money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heck d'ya mean?  What a you guys got yourself mixed up in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need more -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was s'posed to be a no-rough -stuff-type deal -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, but I just - I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  I'm not gonna debate you, Jerry.  The price is now the whole amount.  We want the entire eighty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Chrissakes here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood has been shed.  We've incurred risks, Jerry.  I'm coming into town tomorrow.  Have the money ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we had a deal here!  A deal's a deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IS IT, JERRY?  You ask those three pour souls up in Brainerd if a deal's a deal!  Go ahead, ask 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  The heck d'ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow. Click. Jerry slams down the phone, which immediately rings.  He angrily snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerome Lundegaard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Reilly Deifenbach at GMAC. Sir, I have not yet recieved those vehicle IDs you promised me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah!  I ... those are in the mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lundegaard, that very well may be.  I must inform you, however, that absent the reciept of those numbers by tomorrow afternoon, I will have to refer this matter to our legal department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My patience is at an end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah.

dialogues.speaker: THE CUBICLE
dialogues.text: We are looking at Jerry's cubicle from across the showroo Noise muted by distance, we watch Jerry slam down the reciever, rise to his feet, fling the phone to the floor, raise his desk blotter high over his head with pens and pencils rolling off it and slam it onto his desktop. He stands for a moment, hands on hips, glaring. He stoops and picks up the phone, places it back on the desktop, starts picking up the pens and pencils.

dialogues.speaker: TRACK
dialogues.text: On steam-table bins of food, each identified by a plaque:

dialogues.speaker: FLORENTINE.
dialogues.text: A complementary track shows two rays being pushed along a buffet line, piled high with many foods.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE AND NORM AT A TABLE
dialogues.text: They sit next to each other at a long cafateria-style Formica table, silently eating. A hip with a hissing walkie-talkie enters frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Norm.  How ya doin', Margie? How's the fricasse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty darn good, ya want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I gotta - hey, Norm, I thought you were goin' fishin' up at Mile Lacs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, after lunch. He goes back to his food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha got there? Gary hands her a flimsy.  Marge takes it with one hand an looks, her other hand frozen with a forkful of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The numbers y'asked for, calls made from the lobby pay phone at the Blue Ox.  Two to Minneapolis that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First one's a trucking company, second one's a private residence. A Shep Proudfoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...  A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep Proudfoot.  That's a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah, okay, I think I'll drive down there, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah?  Twin Cities? Norm, who has been eating steadily throughout, looks over Marge with mild interest.  He stares for a beat as he finishes chewing, and them swallows and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Oh, yah?

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN OF LUNDEGAARD HOUSE
dialogues.text: Jerry, Wade, and Stan Grossman sit around the kitchen tab It is night.  The scene is harshly toplit by a hanging fixture.  On the table are the remains of coffee and a cinammon filbert ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit!  I wanna be a part a this thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Wade!  They were real clear! They said they'd call tomorrow, with instructions, and it's gonna be delivered by me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my money, I'll deliver it - what do they care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's got a point there.  I'll handle the call if you want, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  See - they, no, see, they only deal with me.  Ya feel this, this nervousness on the phone there, they're very - these guys're dangerous -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the more reason!  I don't want you - with all due respect, Jerry - I don't want you mucking this up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heck d'ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want my money, they can deal with me.  Otherwise I'm goin' to a professional. He points at a briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  There's a million dollars here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, see -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jerry, you're not sellin' me a damn car.  It's my show here. That's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the way we prefer to handle it, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOWNTOWN RADISSON HOTEL
dialogues.text: Marge is at the reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real good.  How're you today, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real good.  I'm Mrs. Gunderson, I have a reservation. The clerk types into a computer console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure do, Mrs. Gunderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a phone down here, ya think?

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY CORNER
dialogues.text: Marge is on a public phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Detective Sibert?  Yah, this is Marge Gunderson from up Brainerd, we spoke -  Yah.  Well, actually I'm in town here.  I had to do a few things in the Twin Cities, so I thought I'd check in with ya about that USIF search on Shep Proudfoot... Oh, yah?...  Well, maybe I'll go visit with him if I have the...  No, I can find that...  Well, thanks a bunch.  Say, d'ya happen to know a good place for lunch in the downtown area?...  Yah, the Radisson...  Oh, yah?  Is it reasonable?

dialogues.speaker: A GREEN FREEWAY SIGN
dialogues.text: Through a windshield we see a sign for the MINNEAPOLIS INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT.

dialogues.speaker: ROOFTOP PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: The brown Ciera enters and drives lazy S-curves around th few snow-covered cars parked on the roof of the lot. It stops by one car and Carl emerges.  He quickly scans t lot, then kneels in the snow at the back of the parked ca and starts unscrewing its license plate.

dialogues.speaker: EXIT BOOTH
dialogues.text: Carl pulls up and hands the attendant his ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I decided not to park here. The attendant frowns uncomprehendingly at the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  What do you mean, you decided not to park here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just came in.  I decided not to park here. The attendant is still puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, uh...  I'm sorry, sir, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decided not to - I'm, uh, not taking the trip as it turns out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, we do have to charge you the four dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just pulled in here.  I just fucking pulled in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, see, there's a minimum charge of four dollars.  Long-term parking charges by the day. A car behind beeps.  Carl glances back, starts digging fo money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you think, ya know, you're an authority figure.  With that stupid fucking uniform.  Huh, buddy? The attendant doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  King Clip-on Tie here.  Big fucking man. He is peeling off one dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  You know, these are the limits of your life, man.  Ruler of your little fucking gate here.  There's your four dollars.  You pathetic piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAFSON OLDS GARAGE
dialogues.text: Jerry is staring up, mouth agape, at the underside of a c on a hydraulic lift.  Bewildered, he looks about, then as a mechanic passing by, his voice raised over the din of t shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Shep? The mechanic points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talkin' to a cop. Jerry looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Cop? Marge and Shep face each other at the other end of the fl in a grimy and cluttered glassed-in cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said she was a policewoman. Marge and Shep silently talk. Jerry stares, swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Wednesday night? Shep is shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you do reside their at 1425 Fremont Terrace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else residing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Proudfoot, this call came in past three in the morning. It's just hard for me to believe you can't remember anyone calling. Shep says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Now, I know you've had some problems, struggling with the narcotics, some other entanglements, currently on parole -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, associating with criminals, if you're the one they talked to, that right there would be a violation of your parole and would end with you back in Stillwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I saw some rough stuff on your priors, but nothing in the nature of a homicide... Shep stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I know you don't want to be an accessory to something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think you might remember who those folks were who called ya?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Jerry is worriedly pacing behind his desk.  At a noise he looks up. Marge has stuck her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lundegaard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if I could take just a minute of your time here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...  What is it all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Do you mind if I sit down - I'm carrying quite a load here. Marge plops into the chair opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  You're the owner here, Mr. Lundegaard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I...  Executive Sales Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can help me.  My name's Marge Gunderson -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father-in-law, he's the owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  Well, I'm a police officer from up Brainerd investigating some malfeasance and I was just wondering if you've had any new vehicles stolen off the lot in the past couple of weeks - specifically a tan Cutlass Ciera? Jerry stares at her, his mouth open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Mr. Lundegaard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Brainerd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Yah.  Home a Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Babe the Blue Ox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, ya know we've got the big statue there.  So you haven't had any vehicles go missing, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey-dokey, thanks a bunch.  I'll let you get back to your paperwork, then. As Marge rises, Jerry looks blankly down at the papers on the desk in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah, okay. He looks up at Marge's retreating back.  He looks back do at the papers.  He looks over at the phone. he picks up the phone and dials four digits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah, gimmee Shep...  The heck d'ya mean?...  Well, where'd he go?  It's only...  No, I don't need a mechanic - oh, geez - I gotta talk to a friend of his, so, uh ... have him, uh ... oh, geez...

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL BAR
dialogues.text: Marge enters.  She looks around the bar, a rather characterless, lowlit meeting place for business people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge? It is a bald, paunching man of about Marge's age, rising from a booth halfway back.  His features are broad, friendly, Asian-American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike! He approaches somewhat carefully, as if on his second dri They hug and head back toward the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez!  You look great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah - easy there - you do too! I'm expecting, ya know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see that!  That's great! A waitress meets them at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  What can I get ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a Diet Coke. Again she glances about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  This is a nice place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, ya know it's the Radisson, so it's pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're livin' in Edina, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah, couple years now.  It's actually Eden Prarie - that school district.  So Chief Gunderson, then! So ya went and married Norm Son-of- a-Gunderson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah, a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  What brings ya down - are ya down here on that homicide - if you're allowed, ya know, to discuss that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yah, but there's not a heckuva lot to discuss.  What about you, Mike?  Are you married - you have kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yah, I was married.  I was married to -  You mind if I sit over here? He is sliding out of his side of the booth and easing in next to Marge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I was married to Linda Cooksey -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I -  Mike - wyncha sit over there, I'd prefer that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Oh, okay, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just so I can see ya, ya know. Don't have to turn my neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, I unnerstand, I didn't mean to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, that's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, sorry, so I was married to Linda Cooksey - ya remember Linda? She was a year behind us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I remember Linda, yah. She was - yah.  So things didn't work out, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I, and then I been workin' for Honeywell for a few years now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're a good outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, if you're an engineer, yah, you could do a lot worse.  Of course, it's not, uh, it's nothin' like your achievement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like you're doin' really super.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, well, I, uh ... it's not that it didn't work out -  Linda passed away.  She, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, I, uh...  She had leukemia, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a tough, uh ... it was a long -  She fought real hard, Marge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ya know, that's, uh - what can I say?... He holds up his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Better times, huh? Marge clinks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so...  I been so ... and then I saw you on TV, and I remembered, ya know...  I always liked you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I always liked you, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always liked ya so much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mike -  Should we get together another time, ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - I'm sorry!  It's just -  I been so lonely - then I saw you, and... He is weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I'm sorry...  I shouldn't a done this...  I thought we'd have a really terrific time, and now I've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were such a super lady ... and then I...  I been so lonely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mike...

dialogues.speaker: CARLTON CELEBRITY ROOM
dialogues.text: Carl Showalter is sitting at a small table with a tarty- looking blonde in a low-cut gown.  Each holds a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in town on business.  Just in and out.  Ha ha!  A little of the old in-and-out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wuddya do? Carl looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have ya been to the Celebrity Room before?  With other, uh, clients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it depends on the artist. You know, Jose Feliciano, ya got no complaints.  Waiter! The reverse shows a disappearing waiter and the backs of many, many people sitting at tables between us and the ve distant stage.  Jose Feliciano, very small, performs on a spotlit stool.  The acoustics are poor. Carl grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  What is he, deaf?...  So, uh, how long have you been with the escort service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Few munce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya find the work interesting, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: A DIRTY BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Carl is humping the escort. We hear the door burst open. The escort is grabbed and flung out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep!  What the hell are you doing? I'm banging that girl!  Shep!  Jesus Ch - Shep slaps him hard, forehand, backhand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck out of my house! He hauls him up -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shep!  Don't you dare fucking hit me, man!  Don't you - - punches him and flings him away. Carl hits a sofa and we see his bare legs disappear as he flips back over it. Shep enters frame to circle the sofa and kick at Carl beh it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck outta here.  Put me back in Stillwater.  Little fucking shit. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Come on in there! Shep strides to the door, flings it open. A man in boxer shorts stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, brother, it's late -  Unghh! Shep hits him twice, then grabs both of his ears and star banging his head against the wall.
