dialogues.text: ...  Well, I gotta muddy. He is plunking down eight bank-wrapped bundles on the tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  All of it.  All eighty gran. Forty for you... He makes one pile, pockets the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Forty for me.  Sho thishuzh it.  Adiosh. He slaps keys down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  You c'n'ave my truck.  I'm takin' a Shiera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We split that. Carl looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOW THE FUCK DO WE SHPLITTA FUCKIN'
dialogues.text: CAR?  Ya dummy!  Widda fuckin' chainshaw? Grimsrud looks sourly up.  There is a beat.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of us pays the other for half.

dialogues.speaker: FUCKERZH MINE
dialogues.text: Carl waits for an argument, but only gets the steady sour look. Carl pulls out a gun.

dialogues.speaker: FUCKIN' WEEK
dialogues.text: A beat.  Carl returns Grimsrud's stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Are we shquare? Grimsrud says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ... ARE WE SHQUARE
dialogues.text: A beat. Disgusted, Carl pockets the gun and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Fuckin' ash-hole.  And if you shee your friend Shep Proudpfut, tell him I'm gonna NAIL hizh fuckin' ash.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: We are pulling Carl as he walks toward the car.  Behind h we see the cabin door opening.  Carl turns, reacting to t sound. Grimsrud is bounding out wearing mittens and a red hunter cap, but no overcoat.  He is holding an ax. Carl fumbles in his pocket for his gun. Grimsrud swings overhand, burying the ax in Carl's neck.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: In her cruiser, on her two-way.  Through it we hear Lou's voice, heavily filtered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife.  This guy says she was kidnapped last Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day of our homicides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. Marge is peering to one side as she drives, looking throu the bare trees that border the road on a declivity that r down to a large frozen lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this guy is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lundegaard's father-in-law's accountant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gustafson's accountant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we still haven't found Gustafson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crackle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -  looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry - didn't copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still missing.  We're looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy.  And Lundegaard too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.  Where are ya, Margie? We hear, distant but growing louder, harsh engine noise, of a chainsaw or lawnmower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm almost back - I'm driving around Moose Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Gary's loudmouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, the loudmouth.  So the whole state has it, Lundegaard and Gustafson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, it's over the wire, it's everywhere, they'll find 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the car!  There's the car! We are slowing as we approach a short driveway leading do to a cabin.  Parked in front is the brown Cutlass Ciera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My car!  My car!  Tan Ciera!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go in!  Wait for back-up! Marge is straining to look.  The power-tool noise is loud here but still muffled, its source not yet visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Chief Gunderson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy.  Yah, send me back-up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.  Are we the closest PD?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, Menominie only has Chief Perpich and he takes February off to go to Boundary Waters.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Marge pulls her prowler over some distance past the cabin She gets out, zips up her khaki parka and pulls up its fu lined hood. For a moment, she stands listening to the muffled roar of the power tool.  Then, with one curved arm half pressing against, half supporting her belly, she takes slow, ginge steps down the slope, through the deep snow, through the trees angling toward the cabin and the source of the grinding noise. She slogs from tree to tree, letting each one support her downhill-leaning weight for a moment before slogging to t next. The roar grows louder.  Marge stands panting by one tree, her breath vaporizing out of her snorkel hood.  She squin down toward the cabin's back lot. A tall man with his back to us, wearing a red plaid quilt jacket and a hunting cap with earflaps, is laboring over large power tool which his body blocks from view. Marge advances. The man is forcing downward something which engages the roaring power tool and makes harsh spluttering noises. The man is Grimsrud, his nose red and eyes watering from cold, hatflaps pulled down over his ears.  His breath ste as he sourly goes about his work, both hands pressing dow shod foot, as it if were the shaft of a butter churn. The roar is very loud. Marge slogs down to the next tree, panting, looking. Grimsrud forces more of the leg into the machine, which w can now see sprays small wet chunks out the bottom. Marge's eyes shift. A large dark form lies in the snow next to Grimsrud. Grimsrud works on, eyes watering.  With a grunt he bends down out of frame and then re-enters holding a thick log. He uses it to force the leg deeper into the machine. Marge is advancing.  She holds a gun extended toward Grimsrud, who is still turned away. Grimsrud rubs his nose with the back of his hand. Marge closes in, grimacing. Grimsrud's back strains as he puts his weight into the lo that pushes down into the machine. The dark shape in the snow next to his side is the rest o Carl Showalter's body. Marge has drawn to within twenty yards.  When she bellows sounds hollow and distant, her voice all but eaten up by roar of the power tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!  Police!  Turn around and hands up! Startled, Grimsrud scowls.  He turns to face her. He stares. Marge bellows again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Hands up! Conscious of the noise, she shows with a twist of her shoulder the armpatch insignia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Police! Grimsrud stares. With a quick twist, he reaches back for the log, hurls it Marge and then starts running away. Marge twists her body sideways, shielding herself. No need - the heavy log travels perhaps ten yards and lan in the snow several feet short of her. Grimsrud pants up the hill - slow going through the deep snow. Behind him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Halt! She fires in the air. She lowers the gun and carefully sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Halt! She fires. Grimsrud still slogs up the hill - a miss. Marge sights again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Halt! She fires again. Grimsrud pitches forward.  He mutters in Swedish as he reaches down to clutch at his wounded leg. Marge walks toward him, gun trained on him as her other h reaches under her parka and gropes around her waist. It comes out with a pair of handcuffs, which she opens wi a snap of the wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  All right, buddy.  On your belly and your hands clasped behind you.

dialogues.speaker: THE CRUISER
dialogues.text: Marge drives.  Grimsrud sits in the back seat, hands cuff behind him. For a long moment there, he is quiet - only engine hum an the periodic clomp of wheels on pavement seams - as Marge grimly shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  So that was Mrs. Lundegaard in there? She glances up in the rear-view mirror. Grimsrud, cheeks sunk, eyes hollow, looks sourly out at t road. Marge shakes her head. At length:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I guess that was your accomplice in the wood chipper. Grimsrud's head bobs with bumps on the road; otherwise he motionless, reactionless, scowling and gazing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  And those three people in Brainerd. No response. Marge, gazing forward, seems to be talking to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  And for what?  For a little bit of money. We hear distant sirens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  There's more to life than money, you know. She glances up in the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Don't you know that?...  And here ya are, and it's a beautiful day... Grimsrud's hollow eyes stare out. The sirens are getting louder.  Marge pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Well... She leans forward to the dash to give two short signallin WHOOPS on her siren. She turns on her flashers. She leans back with a creak and jangle of utilities. She stares forward, shakes her head.  We hear the dull cl of her flashers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I just don't unnerstand it. Outside it is snowing.  The sky, the earth, the road - al white. A squad car, gumballs spinning, punches through the white It approaches in slow motion. An ambulance punches through after it. Another squad car.

dialogues.speaker: A SHABBY MOTEL
dialogues.text: It stands next to a highway on a snowy, windslept plain. One or two cars dot the parking lot along with an idling police cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM DOORWAY
dialogues.text: We are looking over the shoulders of two uniformed police who stand on either side of the door, their hands resting lightly on their holstered sidearms.  One of them raps at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Anderson... A title fades in:  OUTSIDE OF BISMARK, NORTH DAKOTA After a pause, muffled through the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Anderson, is this your burgundy 88 out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Just a sec.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you open the door, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Yah.  Yah, just a sec. We hear a clatter from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Just a sec... One of the policemen unholsters his gun and nods to someo whose back enters - a superintendent holding a ring of ke This man turns a key in the door and then stands away. The two policemen, guns at the ready, bang into the motel room. The rough hand-held camera rushes in behind them as the t men give the room a two-handed sweep with their guns. The room is empty. Cop one indicates the open bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dale! The two men charge the bathroom, belts jingling, guns at ready, jittery camera behind them rushing to keep pace. A man in boxer shorts is halfway out the bathroom window. The policemen holster their guns and charge the window, a drag Jerry Lundegaard back into the room. His flesh quivers as he thrashes and keens in short, piercing screams. The cops wrestle him to the floor but his palsied thrashi continues.  The policemen struggle to restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call an ambulance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got him okay? Cop One pinions Jerry's arms to the floor and Jerry burst into uncontrolled sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, yah, call an ambulance. Jerry sobs and screams.

dialogues.speaker: A BEDROOM
dialogues.text: We are square on Norm, who sits in bed watching televisio After a long beat, Marge enters frame in a nightie and climbs into bed, with some effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooph! Norm reaches for her hand as both watch the television. At length Norm speaks, but keeps his eyes on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They announced it. Marge looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They announced it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. Marge looks at him, waiting for more, but Norm's eyes sta fixed on the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-cent stamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mallard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm, that's terrific! Norm tries to suppress a smile of pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just the three cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrific!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hautman's blue-winged teal got the twenty-nine cent.  People don't much use the three-cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Pete's - a course they do! Every time they raise the darned postage, people need the little stamps!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they're stuck with a bunch a the old ones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrific. Her eyes go back to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  I'm so proud a you, Norm. Norm murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Margie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Norm. Both of them are watching the TV as Norm reaches out to r a hand on top of her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  Two more months. Marge absently rests her own hand on top of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more months. Hold; fade out.
